questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of an itchy rash. He has no history of skin problems. He had an upper respiratory infection 4 days ago that resolved with acetaminophen and over-the-counter cold medication. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with insulin. He was also diagnosed with hypertension 3 weeks ago and treatment with captopril was initiated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Examination shows rashes at the waistline, trunk, and over the forearms. A photograph of the right forearm is shown. The rashes are nontender and blanch on pressure. There is no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antigen contact with presensitized T lymphocytes is the mechanism underlying contact dermatitis, which are type IV hypersensitivity reactions. These hypersensitivity responses classically appear 48–72 hours after exposure to the antigen (e.g., poison ivy, nickel) and cause pruritic, erythematous, indurated tissue at the site of exposure. This patient's disseminated, nontender rash following an upper respiratory infection suggests a different mechanism.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA deposits in the upper dermis are immunofluorescence findings of dermatitis herpetiformis. Although the rash typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis is pruritic and erythematous, it would take the form of tense, grouped subepidermal vesicles (herpetiform appearance), unlike here. Moreover, the patient's history does not suggest celiac disease or gluten sensitivity, which is usually associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

C) INCORRECT:

The process of IgG and IgM antibody-dependent cellular lysis and phagocytosis is the (cytotoxic) mechanism underlying type II hypersensitivity reactions. Pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid are well-known examples. While bullous pemphigoid often presents with pruritus, both of these conditions would manifest with the formation of blisters. This patient's disseminated, nontender rash following an upper respiratory infection suggests a different immunological mechanism.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired degradation of bradykinin can be caused by ACE inhibitors such as captopril, which is part of this patient's pharmacological regimen. However, increased levels of bradykinin would typically cause angioedema and dry cough, which this patient does not have. Most importantly, bradykinin-mediated angioedema is not associated with pruritic urticaria.
Image Description:

The severely swollen lower lip is most likely angioedema.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune complex formation and deposition are the main mechanisms involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions. This type of reaction accounts for a number of immunological disorders, including certain types of vasculitides, serum sickness, and Arthus reaction, which can present with an itchy, erythematous rash. However, unlike this patient's rash, vasculitis is typically painful and often occurs in conjunction with systemic involvement of joints, lungs, kidneys, and/or GI tract. Serum sickness occurs after administration of antivenom, and an Arthus reaction most commonly occurs after toxoid vaccinations (e.g., tetanus, diphtheria).

F) CORRECT:

Infection-induced urticaria is caused by mast cell activation and the subsequent release of histamine, in response to viral, bacterial, and parasitic pathogens. While acute urticaria following a viral illness is more common in children, it can also happen in adults. Patients typically present with a urticarial rash and the diagnosis is clinical. The condition is usually self-limited and patients may only require symptomatic treatment (e.g., antihistamines).
questions.hint: This patient presents with urticaria following an upper airway infection.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician in October because of an 8-week history of an episodic rash. The last episode occurred three hours ago when he was swimming outdoors. During these episodes, he develops multiple pruritic raised and round red patches over his arms, legs, and chest. He reports that the symptoms resolve within an hour. He is a triathlete and has been training multiple times a day during the last two months. He says that he has often had to interrupt his training because of the rash. His family history is remarkable for asthma in his brother. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.5°F), pulse is 61/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. His lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?

choices.text: No additional management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Direct antiglobulin testing is used to diagnose cold agglutinin disease, which manifests with exposure to cold temperatures. However, cold agglutinin disease is a form of cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia for which CBC would show decreased hemoglobin and RBC count, and increased reticulocyte count. Moreover, clinical features include livedo reticularis and painful acrocyanosis, not urticarial lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are interrupting his daily life and can be potentially life-threatening (e.g., anaphylaxis); therefore, additional management is necessary. In addition, the causative trigger for this patient's chronic inducible urticaria is unclear and should be further investigated.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs), e.g., nifedipine, are the first-line treatment for Raynaud phenomenon, which can be triggered by exposure to cold temperatures. However, Raynaud phenomenon most commonly affects the fingers and toes and progresses with an ischemic, hypoxic, and hyperemic phase, manifesting with pallor, cyanosis, and erythema respectively. Moreover, this condition often manifests with paresthesia or pain, not pruritus. CCBs would not resolve this patient's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic inducible urticaria manifests after exposure to a specific trigger or stimulus (e.g., heat, cold, pressure, vibration, exercise). If chronic inducible urticaria is suspected, provocation and threshold testing should be performed to identify triggers and confirm the diagnosis. During provocation testing, patients are exposed to potential triggers and monitored for the appearance of urticarial lesions. Medications to treat symptoms, such as antihistamines and glucocorticoids, should be suspended for at least 3 days before initiating testing. Provocation tests help differentiate chronic inducible urticaria types, including exercise-induced urticaria, aquagenic urticaria, and cold urticaria, any of which could be causing this patient's symptoms. If cold urticaria is suspected, a cold stimulation test (e.g., ice cube test) should be performed to evaluate the patient's response. If a pruritic wheal develops, the test is considered positive, and the patient should undergo threshold testing with the TempTest to determine the highest temperature at which a reaction would occur. Threshold testing is not necessary for diagnosis but can help patients avoid potentially life-threatening situations (e.g., anaphylaxis when swimming in cold water).

Treatment for chronic inducible urticaria includes trigger avoidance, patient education, and a second-generation H1 antihistamine regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Although H1 antihistamines are part of the preferred management for chronic inducible urticaria, first-generation H1 antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) are typically avoided because of their sedative effects. Second-generation H1 antihistamines (e.g., cetirizine, loratadine) are preferred. The cause of this patient's chronic inducible urticaria should be established before initiating treatment.
questions.hint: This patient has had pruritic wheals for > 6 weeks following exposure to a particular stimulus, which suggests chronic inducible urticaria.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man reports having intermittent hives for the past 2 years, usually every other day and typically in the morning. He also reports spontaneous episodes of eyelid swelling. He has been treating the hives and swelling with diphenhydramine tablets, which initially resulted in a rapid response. However, during the past several months, the hives and angioedema episodes have been more persistent and have not cleared completely. He does not have signs or symptoms of anaphylaxis, any constitutional symptoms, or any identifiable triggers for his symptoms.
What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Counsel the patient to avoid use of acetaminophen
Counsel the patient to avoid eating fish and shellfish

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms have persisted for more than 6 weeks and are therefore consistent with a diagnosis of chronic idiopathic urticaria. The eyelid edema represents dermal edema (angioedema). The patient is otherwise healthy and has no signs of anaphylaxis.

The hives and angioedema of chronic idiopathic urticaria are caused primarily by the activation of mast cells in the skin, which release histamine. The first-line treatment for chronic idiopathic urticaria with angioedema is an oral antihistamine. Although first-generation antihistamines such as diphenhydramine can be used, second-generation antihistamines such as cetirizine, fexofenadine, and loratadine are preferred because they have a longer duration of action and do not cause sedation. If a patient’s symptoms occur only very rarely, the antihistamine can be given intermittently on an as-needed basis. In this case, given the frequency and persistence of the patient’s symptoms, the antihistamine should be used daily, whether the urticaria and angioedema are present or not. An initial dose of cetirizine 10 mg daily is recommended, but if the hives persist, dose escalations and combination therapy with other antihistamines may be required.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for chronic idiopathic urticaria with angioedema is a second-generation long-acting oral antihistamine.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen does not cause exacerbations of chronic urticaria and thus does not need to be avoided. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may exacerbate hives and should be minimized or discontinued (if possible) in patients with chronic urticaria.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic idiopathic urticaria is rarely triggered by foods. In the absence of a clear history of fish as a trigger for a patient’s symptoms, fish avoidance is not necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are effective and often used for the short-term treatment of acute urticaria, they should be avoided, if possible, in patients with chronic urticaria to avoid the long-term adverse effects of systemic glucocorticoid use. This patient’s symptoms are not reported to be acutely worsening, and they have improved with antihistamines in the past, making glucocorticoids unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical diphenhydramine may be soothing for individual lesions, and topical glucocorticoids may reduce the inflammation and itch of acute urticaria, but in general, topical agents have little or no role in the long-term management of chronic urticaria.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a 7-week history of daily hives and one episode of lip swelling without throat tightening or abdominal pain. He has had no preceding illness, fevers, weight loss, or joint pain. His lesions are intermittent (with each lasting <24 hours), do not leave a residual mark, and are characterized by itch without pain or burning.
The patient has a history of hypertension but does not currently take any prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, or herbal supplements. He has had no recent travel, new bedding, or contact with pets.
Examination reveals a few scattered, round, pink, edematous, indurated plaques with central pallor (figure). The rest of the examination and comprehensive review of systems is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Perform a skin biopsy of one of the plaques
Obtain complete blood count with differential interpretation
Prescribe a therapeutic trial of antihistamines
Measure thyroid-stimulating hormone and antithyroid peroxidase antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complement C4 should be checked in cases of isolated angioedema to screen for C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency; it commonly affects the skin or mucosal surfaces of the upper airways and gastrointestinal tracts. The presence of concomitant urticaria eliminates this as a potential diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A skin biopsy should be performed if urticarial vasculitis is suspected. This condition is characterized by hives that last >24 hours, are painful or burning rather than pruritic, appear purpuric or ecchymotic, leave residual hyperpigmentation after resolution, or are accompanied by joint pain or fevers.

C) INCORRECT:

If a 2-week trial of treatment fails, a workup may include a complete blood count with differential interpretation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has chronic urticaria (hives occurring on a regular basis for more than 6 weeks) and an episode of angioedema, which accompanies urticaria in approximately 40% of cases. A careful history should be obtained to identify a possible trigger or underlying systemic disorder.

Identifying an etiology is not as common in chronic urticaria as in acute-onset urticaria. If no specific trigger or underlying condition is identified for chronic urticaria, a 2-week trial of scheduled nonsedating H1-antihistamines (often in escalated doses) is recommended as first-line management, with no initial laboratory testing.

If this 2-week trial fails, a workup may include a complete blood count with differential interpretation and thyroid studies with thyroid-stimulating hormone and antithryoid peroxidase antibodies.

Key learning point: A workup for underlying causes of urticaria should be performed if urticaria persists for more than 6 weeks and fails to respond to routinely administered nonsedating H1-antihistamines.

E) INCORRECT:

If a 2-week trial of treatment fails, a workup may include thyroid studies with thyroid-stimulating hormone and antithyroid peroxidase antibodies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after consuming lobster at a dinner party. He reports generalized pruritus and a new rash on his chest and arms. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild perioral edema. The appearance of the skin rash is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with acute urticaria following exposure to a known allergen, a classic type I hypersensitivity reaction. Second-generation antihistamines are the first-line treatment for symptomatic management of urticaria alongside trigger avoidance. The patient has localized skin manifestations without systemic signs of anaphylaxis, making antihistamines the most appropriate initial therapy. Treatment should be scheduled rather than on-demand until the hives resolve. Referral to an allergist for allergy testing can also be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis when diagnostic criteria are met, including hypotension, respiratory involvement, or multi-system organ involvement. While this patient has mild perioral edema, he lacks cardiovascular or respiratory compromise that would warrant immediate epinephrine administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Tryptase levels can support a diagnosis of mast cell activation in Type I reactions, but laboratory confirmation is not necessary when the clinical presentation is clear. This test does not alter immediate management, and results are not available immediately in the acute setting due to a prolonged turnaround time.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids are typically reserved for severe urticaria exacerbations or may be considered in Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reactions with significant inflammation. The acute onset and urticarial pattern in this case do not warrant initial corticosteroid therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids might be appropriate for localized contact dermatitis from Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reactions. However, this patient's systemic urticaria with rapid onset after allergen exposure requires systemic treatment rather than topical therapy alone.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with generalized pruritic wheals 45 minutes after eating lobster. She denies dyspnea, chest tightness, or abdominal pain. Vital signs are T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); BP, 125/75; P, 84; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. Physical examination shows well-circumscribed, erythematous, raised lesions of various sizes on her trunk and extremities that blanch with pressure. She has no stridor, wheezing, or swelling. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform skin biopsy for histopathologic examination
Obtain chest x-ray and arterial blood gas

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuous cardiac monitoring is not required for isolated urticaria without cardiovascular symptoms. This patient has stable vital signs and no evidence of cardiovascular compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is not indicated for typical acute urticaria. Biopsy is considered for atypical lesions that persist longer than 48 hours, are painful rather than pruritic, or when urticarial vasculitis is suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray and arterial blood gas are not indicated for isolated urticaria without respiratory symptoms. The patient has normal oxygen saturation and no dyspnea, stridor, or wheezing.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with acute urticaria following allergen exposure and has isolated skin manifestations and stable vital signs. Oral antihistamines are the first-line treatment for acute urticaria.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis, not for isolated skin manifestations. This patient has stable vital signs and does not have cardiovascular, respiratory, or significant gastrointestinal symptoms and therefore does not meet the criteria for anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with widespread itchy hives that developed 4 hours ago after eating at a seafood restaurant. He denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or difficulty breathing. Vital signs: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 78 bpm, RR 16/min, O2 sat 98%. Examination shows well-circumscribed erythematous wheals on his chest, back, and arms without facial swelling or respiratory distress. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are indicated for severe urticaria exacerbations and is not the most appropriate initial management for this patient's urticaria.

B) INCORRECT:

First-generation antihistamines should be used with caution due to potential serious adverse effects including sedation and motor function impairment; an alternative agent is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine are first-line treatment for acute urticaria.

D) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated when diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis are met. However, this patient does not have anaphylaxis.

E) INCORRECT:

While acute urticaria is often self-limited, symptomatic management is the standard approach and should be provided for all patients.
